Topic.Title: According to techstrategy . . . Amazon's purchase of TI's mobile chip unit . . .

Message.Msg: Almost anything Amazon can buy with its overpriced currency is good for it in terms of preserving long term value, although that will still be far lower than this. Having said that, TI's board should be sued by shareholders if they agree to anything other than an all cash deal... If Amazon uses cash, it will just accelerate its demise. That would be open season for all shorts. In summary, it makes no sense except as a vehicle to preserve some value of a massively overvalued currency known as Amazon's stock.

Message.Title: AMZN heading to wrong direction.
Message.Msg: I used to split my purchases between EBAY and AMZN. But this quarter I had about 80 orders from EBAY but only one from AMZN. A book by the way. AMZN is trying to build their own distribution centers and squeeze out the small vendors. Bezos doesn't understand these small vendors selling hard to find merchandises is the reason that made AMZN great. Low price can take you so far. And I don't think AMZN can win the price war against Wal-Mart and Best Buy. I predict AMZN sales shrink dramatically in the next quarter and Bezo will be back to square one like 1999. It turns out that Bezos is not a genius. Greed gets the best of him. Buy EBAY and sell AMZN!

Message.Title: USA FRAUD STREET CASINO WILL CRASH AND BURN & RIOTS IN 2013
Message.Msg: sign of times is here SCAMAZON BELOW $100 INTO MID TEENS end of 2013 Big hedge fund shut down may spread Big hedge fund shut down may spread By Jim Kim Octavian Advisors, a hedge fund that focused on distressed investments, has decided to shutter its operations following some big losses. "While we have significantly outperformed the international equity markets we focus on over a multi-year period, we have not generated attractive absolute returns in an exceptionally difficult environment. The last eighteen months have been particularly difficult," the firm wrote to clients, as reported by Reuters, which also reported that the fund was down 11 percent through August. Is an 11 percent loss enough to cause most $1 billion hedge funds to shut down, and return funds to limited partners? Lots of funds have suffered worse. Just look at John Paulson, his flagship funds have been hit with even bigger losses. While the two funds have fared well recently, they are still down for the year, and after a disastrous 2011, it will be a long time before they get back to their high water marks. So is Octavian pulling the trigger a bit early? Shouldn't they be willing to stick it out? It's hard to know what went into the decision-making process. One could argue that the managers looked into the future and just couldn't see a path to outsized gains, though once-toxic assets seem to be faring better now. Management might have decided that trying to get back to even would take forever, so why not throw in the towel and avoid the chance of bigger losses for investors later. It's also possible that the funds' losses are bigger than publicly known, and perhaps extend for a longer time horizon. In any case, more funds have been shuttering this year, compared with last year. Each no doubt has a different story to tell. For more:

Message.Title: Amazon the neo-conglomerate
Message.Msg: It used to be that conglomerates traded at a discount to the sum of their businesses as investors preferred pure plays. Amazon is effectively becoming the equivalent of the old conglomerate, with a multitude of business lines, except is trading at a premium to the sum of its parts.

Message.Title: So what happens to AMZN when market crashes
Message.Msg: Does it go to 50 like 2008? "So while it is true that stocks have advanced a few percent since March, my strong view is that this is good fortune born entirely of investor anticipation of ECB and Fed announcements that are now behind us. Indeed, the S&P 500 is lower now than when QEternity was announced, and on a volume-weighted basis, is also lower than when Draghi threw his hail-Mary pass over the Bundesbank. By our estimate, the present ensemble of market conditions is associated with a historical rate of loss in the S&P 500 approaching -50% annualized. Now, I donâ€™t expect conditions to be similarly negative for a full year - the typical course is for the market to transition to less negative conditions after an initial hard decline. But I continue to believe that the gain in the S&P 500 since March, when our return/risk estimates became overwhelmingly negative, should not be the basis for complacency here. " Fromm hussmanfunds market commentary of the week.

Topic.Title: AMZN is a con. Why else do they change business model daily?

Message.Msg: All the market pundits wonder why retail keeps pulling money. All one has to do is look at the relative valuation of Intel and Amazon and it becomes crystal clear. One of the most innovative companies in the history of the world, which generates huge cash, has a great balance sheet and still dominates the processor landscape, is worth less than a internet retailer which has almost never generated significant cash nor made large profits -- all on a story. As long as the institutions play these games, they will destroy trust and more cash will move to non financial assets... Folks thought they could compel retail investors back into stocks. They are wrong. The distrust is too great. Until the losses are realized, people will keep scaling out.

Topic.Title: AMZN is a con. Why else do they change business model daily?

Message.Msg: No disrepect, but 'bozoes' should dress up in a clown suit for the annual shareholder meeting. Wallstreet would bump this thing up 20$ a share just on the 'potential'.

Topic.Title: Amazon Buys $1 Billion Of Real Estate

Message.Msg: "Still $4 billion in the bank..........." A $115 billion company with $4 billion in the bank and an upcoming quarter with losses, now that is what I call a very profitable company and very cheap stock.

Topic.Title: Amazon Buys $1 Billion Of Real Estate

Message.Msg: Kenji: Look at current assets and current liabilities. That cash is required to pay vendors. If Apple (who Amazon is targeting) and a few others every refused to extend extended payment terms and the working capital went from negative to positive, Amazon would implode quickly. Not quite sure why Apple, Samsung and the other companies that make up much of Amazon's sales want to help it. Consumers can always buy their products elsewhere... It is a retailer without power over the consumer... It just happened to have an artificial competitive advantage via the online tax subsidy before that enabled it to undercut on price and maintain margins... The uncollected tax exceeds Amazon's net margins...
